Carbonylation of methanol to methyl acetate over Cu/TiO2-SiO2 catalysts: Influence of copper precursors Xianjie Meng a b Lijing Yuan a b Heqin Guo a ⁎ Bo Hou a Congbiao Chen a Dekui Sun a Jungang Wang a Debao Li a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Science, Taiyuan 030001, Shanxi, PR China State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion Institute of Coal Chemistry Chinese Academy of Science Taiyuan Shanxi 030001 PR China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100039, PR China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100039 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract In the present study, three kinds of copper/titania-silica mixed oxides (Cu/TS) catalysts were prepared using copper chloride, copper nitrate, and copper acetate as copper precursors by the sol-gel method. The catalytic performance was tested in the vapor phase carbonylation of methanol free of halide. The characterization results showed that the interaction between copper and support was the strongest on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst, leading to the highest copper dispersion and the most surface Cu+ species. As a result, the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst obtained the largest absorption capacity of CO and the maximum amount of Lewis acid sites. The catalytic performance results showed that the space time yield (STY) of methyl acetate (MA) was positively correlated with the content of surface Cu+ species and the specific surface area of the Cu+ cations (SCu(I)). Therefore, the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst obtained the highest STYMA of 1.619 mol/h.kgcat. Moreover, the STYMA per Cu+ site was inversely proportional to the copper particle size, indicating that the carbonylation of methanol to MA is a structure-sensitive reaction. And the methanol conversion was positively correlated with the amount of surface acid sites. Furthermore, the active sites for the synthesis of methyl formate and dimethyl ether were also studied. Keywords Carbonylation Methanol Methly acetate Precursor 1 Introduction In recent years, the use of natural gas as an alternative fuel is becoming more and more interesting due to the increasing availability of shale gas in United States. The sharp drop in the price of natural gas has provided a high profitability for the domestic methanol production, leading to a drastic surplus of methanol [1]. Many efforts have been made on the conversion of methanol into value-added products, such as catalytic oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde [2,3], dehydration of methanol to dimethyl ether (DME) [4,5], dehydrogenation of methanol to methyl formate (MF) [6,7], carbonylation of methanol to acetic acid [8,9] and oxidative carbonylation of methanol to dimethyl carbonate (DMC) [10,11]. Among these reported technologies, the vapor phase carbonylation of methanol to methyl acetate (MA) free of halide attracted much attention because of the advantages of environmentally friendly and facile catalyst separation [12–14]. Several types of heterogeneous catalysts were used in the vapor phase carbonylation of methanol free of halide [9,12,15,16]. Among them, the copper-based catalysts deserved further study due to their high efficiency and low cost [17]. While, the previous studies were centered on the silica-alumina molecular sieves or activated carbon supported copper catalysts [16,18,19]. Litter attention has been paid to the oxides supported copper catalyst, which has good stability and adjustable acidity. For instance, the titanium-silicon mixed oxides supported copper catalyst was applied in the oxidative carbonylation of methanol, which could activate both CO and methanol to generate DMC [20]. Furthermore, our previous works showed that titanium-silicon mixed oxides supported copper catalysts exhibited satisfactory catalytic performance in the carbonylation of methanol to MA [21]. And it was found that the surface Cu+ species are the metal active sites for the carbonylation reaction. Thus, it seems that an efficient catalyst for the carbonylation of methanol should contain a large amount of surface Cu+ species. And this gives an important inspiration for the catalyst design in the methanol carbonylation. Many factors, such as preparation method, copper loading, support material, metal addition and precursor type as well as pretreatment condition can influence the distribution of surface copper species on the copper-based catalysts [21–27]. Among these factors, the type of copper precursor has significant impacts on the dispersion, coordination environment of copper as well as the interaction between copper and support, which strongly affect the catalytic performance [27–29]. For example, Zhang et al. reported that the copper precursors significantly affected the interaction between CuO and Co3O4, which further affected its catalytic performance in the reaction of NO reduction by CO [30]. Thus, it can be deduced that the type of copper precursors may also influence the catalytic performance of the copper/titania-silica mixed oxides (Cu/TS) catalysts in the carbonylation of methanol. As far as we know, very little work has been devoted to this research. In the present work, three types of Cu/TS catalysts were prepared by the sol-gel method using copper chloride, copper nitrate, and copper acetate as copper precursors, respectively. The catalysts were characterized by inductively coupled plasma, N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction, temperature-programmed reduction of CO, N2O titration, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia and Fourier transform infrared. The catalytic performance was tested on the methanol carbonylation reaction. The effect of copper precursors on the structure, metal distribution and surface acidity of catalysts as well as catalytic performance was studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysis preparation 2.1.1 Materials The chemicals used in this study include: tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, AR, Tianjin Kermel), tetrabutyl titanate (TBOT, AR, Sinopharm), acetylacetone (ACET, AR, Sigma Aldrich), absolute ethanol (EtOH, Fangzheng Reagent), copper chloride (CuCl2·2H2O, Tianjin Guangfu), copper nitrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Merck), copper acetate (Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O, Sigma Aldrich), hydrochloric acid (HCl, SRL), nitric acid (HNO3, SRL) and acetic acid (CH3COOH, SRL). 2.1.2 Catalyst synthesis Cu/TS catalysts with the Ti/Si ratio of 1 and copper loading of 10 wt% were prepared from three different copper precursors by the sol-gel method. In a typical synthesis, 41.67 g of TEOS, 68.07 g of TBOT and 2 g of ACET were mixed in 178 g of EtOH and stirred for 30 min. Calculated amounts of copper precursor (copper nitrate, copper chloride or copper acetate) dissolved in 30 ml corresponding acid solutions (3 mol/L, HCl, HNO3 or CH3COOH) were added to the above mixture during stirring. Then, the mixed solution was heated under reflux for 3 h to form a sol. The obtained gel was aged at 30 °C for 24 h each. The wet solid was kept at 70 °C for 10 h and then kept at 120 °C for 12 h in an oven. Finally, the materials were calcined in a muffle furnace at 400 °C (1 °C /min heating rate, air flow) for 4 h. The final solid samples were marked as 10Cu/TS (Cl) (chloride source), 10Cu/TS (N) (nitrate source) and 10Cu/TS (C) (acetate source) respectively. 2.2 Characterization The elemental composition of the catalysts was analyzed using the ICP-OES Thermo Fisher Scientific iCAP 6300 elemental analysis instrument. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and specific surface areas were measured using an Autosorb-iQ2 instrument. X-ray powder diffraction was performed on a PANalytical X’Pert3 using Mo Kα radiation operating at 40 KV and 30 mA. The pyridine adsorption infrared spectroscopy (Py-IR) spectra of catalysts were employed on a Thermo Nicolet 7000 spectrometer. And the diffuse reflectance FTIR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Magna 750 infrared spectrometer supplied with a MCT detector. CO-temperature programmed reduction measurements and NH3-temperature programmed desorption were carried out using tube furnace connected on-line mass spectrometry. For the catalyst analysis, a 5 vol% CO or NH3 in Ar gas mixture was used. N2O titration was carried out using a TP-5080 chemical adsorption instrument with a thermal conductivity detector. XPS and Auger electron spectroscopy (XAES) were carried out using a Kratos AXIS ULTRA DLD electron spectrometer with Al Kα X-rays (hv = 1486.6 eV) radiation. 2.3 Carbonylation reaction The vaper phase carbonylation of methanol was performed in a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor with an inner diameter of 12 mm. The catalyst sample (2 g, 20–40 mesh) was packed in the reactor and the height of catalyst bed was approximately 10 mm. The catalyst was reduced in pure CO at 230 °C for 4 h. After reduction, the reactant of methanol was injected continuously from the top of the reactor through a high-pressure pump. The molar ratio CO/methanol was 5.67 with the reaction pressure of 1.0 MPa. The liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) of methanol was 1800 h−1. The reaction products were analyzed on a gas chromatograph (GC-950) with a Propack T column, a TDX-01 column and a capillary column HP-Plot/Q equipped with thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The main product included dimethyl ether (DME), methyl formate (MF) and methyl acetate (MA). Several catalysts in the same experimental conditions were taken and analyzed by GC to ensure repeatability. The product selectivity was calculated on carbon molar base: S i = Y i n i /∑Y i n i ×100%, where i is the reaction product, S i is the selectivity of product i, Y i is the number of carbon atom of product i, and n i is the molar of product i. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Texture and structural characteristics of the catalysts Fig.1 (a) presents the low-pressure N2 adsorption/desorption isothermal curves at −196 °C for the catalysts. All the synthesized catalysts demonstrate a typeⅠsorption isotherm based on IUPAC, typical of microporous materials [31]. Besides, the hysteresis loop at the relative pressure of 0.45 is only observed on the 10Cu/TS (N) and 10Cu/TS (C) catalysts, which is characteristic of mesoporous materials [32]. This shows that the copper precursor has an influence on the structure of the catalysts. The pore distribution of the catalysts is calculated by the Nonlocal Density Functional Theory (NLDFT) (see Fig.1 (b)). As it can be seen, the copper-containing catalysts exhibit similar microporous structure to the TS support, with the pore size centered at about 1.6 nm. While, the distribution of mesopores higher than 3 nm on the four catalysts is different from each other, which may be due to the different interaction between the copper precursor and the support. According to the previous literature [33], these mesopores may be attributed to the chrysocolla-like structure formed by silica and copper. Moreover, the surface area of the catalysts is also different, which reaches the highest the value (281.2 m2/g) on the 10Cu/TS (N) catalyst. The FT-IR spectrum is used to investigate the composition and structure of the catalysts. Before recording the spectra, the catalysts are reduced by CO at 230 °C for 3 h and purged by Ar. As shown in Fig.2 , the FT-IR peak at about 1630 cm−1 is ascribed to the bending vibration of adsorbed water molecular [34]. The peak at 1220 cm−1 and the shoulder peak at about 1140 cm-1 can be attributed to the asymmetric Si-O-Si stretching vibration, and the bands at 840 cm-1 can be assigned to the symmetric stretching of Si-O-Si [35]. In addition, the peak at about 970 cm−1 is closely related to the vibration of Ti-O-Si, which demonstrates the mixing and interaction between Si and Ti atoms [35–37]. After the introduction of copper, the peak intensity of Si-O-Si and Ti-O-Si bond all decrease. It may be due to the copper species covering the surface of the support. Simultaneously, these two types of peak all have obvious shiftward to low wavenumber (see the red dotted line in Fig.2). This is probably due to the copper species are connected to the support to form Si-O-Cu and Ti-O-Cu during the preparation progress [38]. Moreover, the redshift of the infrared peak attributed to Si-O-Si bond on the 10Cu/TS (N) and 10Cu/TS (C) catalysts are more obvious than that on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst. While the redshift of the infrared peak corresponding to Ti-O-Si bond is larger when copper chloride is used as the copper precursor. This phenomenon shows that the interaction between the copper species and the support is different on these three catalysts. The copper species are mainly connected to the Si-O-Si bond on the 10Cu/TS (N) and 10Cu/TS (C) catalysts. However, the copper species are mainly connected to the Ti-O-Si bond on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst. It is known that the chemical environment of the O in Ti-O-Si is different from that of in Si-O-Si [39]. Since Ti has less electronegativity than Si, the electron density around O in Ti-O-Si is larger than that in Si-O-Si. And the high electron density can increase the combination between copper species and the support. It can be inferred that the interaction between the copper chloride precursor and the support is stronger than that of the other two precursors. Fig.3 presents the XRD diffractogram of the catalysts before and after reduction. For the fresh catalysts, the typical diffraction peak of SiO2 at 2θ = 25° is observed on all catalysts without the detection of typical peaks corresponding to crystalline titanium and copper phases, indicating the high dispersion of titanium and copper. After the introduction of copper, the SiO2 peaks are obviously broadened, which is apparent on the 10Cu/TS (C) and 10Cu/TS (N) catalysts, indicating the smaller grain size of SiO2 on these two catalysts. After reduction by CO at 230 °C for 3 h, the typical diffraction peaks of Cu° at 2θ = 43.35, 50.45 and 74.21° (JCPDS#85-1326) are detected on all Cu/TS catalysts [40]. In addition, the typical diffraction peaks of Cu+ at 2θ = 37.83, 48.04 and 54.85° [41] (JCPDS#75-1531) are more evident on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst than that on the 10Cu/TS (C) and 10Cu/TS (N) catalysts, which indicates that the amount of surface Cu+ species on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst is more than that on the other two catalysts. In addition, the size of the Cu° grains is calculated according to the Scherrer Equation and summarized in Table 1 . It is found that the size of the Cu° grains on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst is larger. Moreover, it is noteworthy that the diffraction peaks of Cu° shift to the higher angle for the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst. Taking the diffraction peak of Cu(111) at about 43.35° as an example, it shifts to the high-angle by about 0.2°(see the enlarged figure). According to the Bragg equation (2dsinθ = nλ), the increase of diffraction angle indicates a decrease of the interplanar spacing. This means that the smaller ions in the support may be doped into the larger face-centered cubic copper lattice [42,43]. This result may be due to the strong interaction between the copper species and the support. This phenomenon is consistent with the results of FTIR and CO-TPR (see below). 3.2 Surface metal state of the catalysts In order to further elucidate the interaction between the copper species and the support on the Cu/TS catalysts, CO-TPR characterization is carried out (see Fig.4 ). Two reduction peaks at about 210 °C and 240 °C, marked as α and β, respectively, are observed on all Cu/TS catalysts. As there is no reduction peak for the TS support, these peaks should be attributed to the reduction of copper species. According to the reported literature [44–46], the first peak can be ascribed to the reduction of surface oligomeric or bulk CuO species and the second peak is due to the reduction of isolated Cu2+ species. As it can be seen, the reduction temperature observed on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst is higher than that of the other two Cu/TS catalysts, indicating a stronger interaction between copper chloride and the support. In order to further quantitatively describe the distribution of the copper species on the three catalysts, the area of each reduction peak is calculated (see Table 1). As it can be seen, the area of α peak is larger for the 10Cu/TS (C) and 10Cu/TS (N) catalysts, indicating more oligomeric CuO species. While, the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst exhibits the largest area of the β peak, indicating a higher content of isolated Cu2+ species. In the carbonylation reaction, the metal sites are responsible for activating CO, which is the key step for MA synthesis [21]. Therefore, CO is used as an infrared probe molecule to prove the distribution and function of the copper species. As shown in Fig.5 , the adsorption peak of CO on the surface of the reduced catalyst is obviously asymmetric. This is a characteristic of simultaneous existence of multiple peaks, which can be fitted to four peaks [47]. The main peak at around 2120 cm−1 is evidently due to Cu+−CO linear species [48]. The band at 2163 cm−1 is typical of CO adsorbed on titanium cations with very low electrophilicity [49]. In addition, the weak band at around 2140 cm−1 is assigned to ν s modes of Cu+-(CO)2 species, the respective symmetric modes being at about 2100 cm−1 [47,50]. It is noteworthy that the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst obtains a larger absorption peak corresponding to Cu+−CO (see Table 2 ) than the other two Cu/TS catalysts. This phenomenon indicates that there are more Cu+ species on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst surface. In addition, the wavenumber of the Cu+-CO absorption peak is higher on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst than that of the other two catalysts. According to the literature [51], the blue-shift of the IR peak means that the interaction between the atoms is greater. In other words, the interaction between copper species and the support is stronger on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst, which is consistent with the CO-TPR and XRD results. To clarify the reason why the interaction between the copper chloride and the support is stronger, the xerogel of the catalysts before calcining are characterized by thermogravimetry (TG) analysis. As shown in Fig.S1-3 (ESI), it is apparent that the raw xerogel for the 10Cu/TS(Cl) catalyst has one more weight-loss process at about 350 °C than the other two catalysts. According to the previous literature [52], it is attributed to the release of HCl, which may be due to the interaction of molten CuCl2 with H+ sites in the hydroxyl groups of the xerogel structure. This combination is similar to ion exchange, which enhances the interaction between copper species and the support. And this corollary can be confirmed by the Py-IR results. The XPS technology is used to characterize the surface composition of the catalysts. All binding energies are corrected by assigning C1s to 284.5 eV. Firstly, the atomic percentage of copper (Cu/(Cu + Ti + Si)) on the catalyst surface is calculated according to the Equation1 (see in ESI) and summarized in Table 2. The results show that the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst has more surface copper atoms than the other two catalysts. The Cu2p XP spectra of the 10Cu/TS catalysts before reduction are shown in Fig.6 (a), the two peaks centered at about 935 and 955 eV are attributed to Cu2p3/2 and Cu2p1/2, respectively [53]. The 2p3/2 main peak at 935 eV and the satellite peak at about 940–945 eV are characteristic of Cu2+ species [54,55]. Moreover, the binding energy of the Cu2p3/2 is higher on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst than that on the other two catalysts, indicating a stronger interaction between copper species and the support. This is consistent with the above results. After reduction by CO, the binding energy of Cu 2p3/2 shifts to 932.5 eV and the satellite peak disappears (see in Fig.6 (b)). This is due to the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu° or/and Cu+ [38]. However, it is difficult to discriminate the copper species with low valence (Cu+ and Cu°) by XPS because of the similar binding energy between Cu+ and Cu° species. So the in situ X-ray induced Auger spectra (XAES) is employed to distinguish between the Cu° and Cu+ species. As shown in Fig.7 , each Cu LMM XAES spectrum contains one more component because of the broad and asymmetrical peak shape [56]. By overlapping peak resolving, the peaks at 921.2 eV and 916 eV are ascribed to Cu° and Cu+, respectively [38]. Base on the area of Cu° and Cu+, the ratio of Cu+/ (Cu+ + Cu°) is calculated and listed in Table 2. It is found that this value gets the maximum of 61.54% on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst. Additionally, the other two catalysts have the similar values, which are 38.12% and 36.99%, respectively. This result indicates that the surface content of Cu+ on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst is higher than that on the other two catalysts, consistent with the CO-FTIR result. In order to further quantitatively analyze the copper dispersion on the surface of the catalysts, N2O titration experiment is carried out. These results are summarized in Table 2. As it can be seen, the copper dispersion on the reduced 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst reaches 26.73%. While the copper dispersions on the 10Cu/TS (N) and 10Cu/TS (C) are only 19.57% and 19.28%, respectively. Combined with the ICP result, the amount of surface copper is calculated (see Table 2). As it can be seen, the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst has the maximum amount of surface copper content, with the value as 0.406 mmol/g, which is much higher than that of the other two catalysts. And this result is consistent with the atom ratio of Cu/(Cu + Ti + Si) obtained from XPS results. Furthermore, the number of different copper species including Cu+ and Cu° are calculated based on the surface copper content and the XPS results. The results show that the number of surface Cu+ species on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst reaches 0.241 mmol/g, which is much higher than that on the other two catalysts. Moreover, the surface metallic Cu area is calculated by the equations reported by Van Der Grift et al [21,57]. And the surface area of Cu+ is calculated through the surface area of Cu° and the ratio of Cu+ species, assuming that the Cu+ ions and Cu° atoms have same atomic sensitivity factors and occupy same areas [58]. These results are summarized in Table 2. It is found that the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst shows the higher specific surface area of both Cu+ and Cu° than the other two catalysts. And the highest specific surface area of Cu+ ions (25.72 m2/g) is achieved on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst, which may be attributed to its higher copper dispersion and the stronger interaction between copper species and the support. Combined with the CO-FTIR result, the functional relationship between the peak area of Cu+-CO (ACu(I)) and the specific surface area of Cu+ ions (SCu(I)) is compiled and shown in Fig.S4. This perfect linear relationship confirms that the qualitative and quantitative measurements of the Cu° and Cu+ surface areas are accurate and reliable, which establishes a solid foundation for further investigations. Previous studies have shown that the Cu+ species are the active sites for the carbonylation [16,21]. By analyzing the distribution of copper species on the Cu/TS catalysts with different copper precursors, it is found that copper precursors greatly affect the distribution of metal centers on the catalyst surface. That is, although chlorine does not participate in the carbonylation reaction, it favors the dispersion of copper on the surface of the support. Moreover, the presence of chlorine stabilizes the copper species to some extent, which favors the formation of Cu+ species. 3.3 Surface acidity of the catalysts It has been generally accepted that the strength and amount of acid sites of the catalysts are key factors in the carbonylation reaction [25]. In this work, the surface acidity of the catalysts is firstly investigated through NH3-TPD technology. As it can be seen from Fig.8 (a), the TS support presents a broad peak centered at about 200 °C, with the amount reaching 584 × 10−3 mmol/g. After the introduction of copper, the number of these acid sites decreases. And the decreasing trend is much profound on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst. From the results of XPS and N2O titration, it is known that the surface copper content on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst is the highest. Thus, it can be deduced that the least number of acid sites on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) before reduction is due to the coverage of copper species on the weak acid sites. After reduction by CO, the surface acidity of catalysts has obvious change except for the TS support (see Fig.8 (b)). As it can be seen, apart from the weak acid peak at about 200 °C, another obvious peak at 350 °C appears for the copper-containing catalysts, which is assigned to NH3 desorption from the medium strong acid sites. These new sites may be closely related to some low state copper species, such as Cu+ species [53]. Then, the amount of the two acidic sites is calculated by deconvolution and shown in Table 3 . The results show that the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst has the least total acid sites but the most medium strong acid sites, which may be attributed to the abundant Cu+ species on its surface. As shown in Fig.S5, the linear relationship between the medium strong acid sites and the surface Cu+ species proves the above inference. Fig. 9 presents the FTIR spectra of adsorbed pyridine in the range of 1400–1700 cm–1. All catalysts exhibit the characteristic bands assigned to pyridinium ions on Brönsted acid sites (1540 and 1630 cm–1) and pyridine molecules coordinated to Lewis acid sites (1450 and 1610 cm–1), respectively. Moreover, the band at 1490 cm–1 is observed for all catalysts, which is attributed to the contribution of pyridine interacting with both Lewis and Brönsted acid sites [59]. It is noteworthy that the characteristic peak at 1450 cm−1 corresponding to Lewis acid site has a significant blue shift after introducing copper species. This blue shift may be caused by the strong interaction between the pyridine ring and the Lewis acid sites produced by the copper species. The amount of Brönsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites are calculated by their ratio and total acid sites (see Table 3). The results show that the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst has more Lewis acid sites, which is directly related to the abundant Cu+ species (see XPS and N2O titration results) [60]. While the amount of Brönsted acid sites is significantly less on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst. It is known that the Brönsted acid sites are provided by the bridging hydroxyl groups (Si-O-Ti) on the support [61,62]. The decrease of the Brönsted acid sites may be due to the replacement of the bridging hydroxyl protons on the support surface by the copper species [20,52,63]. This conclusion is consistent with the FTIR results in Section 3.1. 3.4 Catalytic activity The catalytic performance of the support and Cu/TS catalysts are shown in Table 4 . For the TS support, the methanol conversion is 29.81% with DME as the only product. After the introduction of copper, the methanol conversion and the product selectivity change significantly. The methanol conversion on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst is similar to that of the TS support. While it increases significantly on the 10Cu/TS (N) and 10Cu/TS (C) catalysts. Moreover, the product distribution undergoes a significant change after the introduction of copper. And the MA and MF are only produced in the Cu/TS catalysts, indicating that the copper species provide the necessary active centers for the formation of MA and MF. It is known that the synthesis of all the three products requires methoxy species [6,16,64], which are generated on the acidic sites. Therefore, the methanol conversion might be related to the surface acidity of the catalysts. In order to explore the relationship between the methanol conversion and surface acidity, the correlation of Xmethanol with the amount of acid sites of different intensities are investigated (see Fig.S6 and Fig.10 (a)). It is found that the Xmethanol is only positively correlated with the amount of total acid sites of the catalysts. And the highest conversion is obtained over the 10Cu/TS (C) catalyst, which has the most acid sites. Moreover, the results show that the STY of MA reaches the highest value (1.619 mol/ h.kgcat) on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst, followed by the 10Cu/TS (N) catalyst and the lowest on the 10Cu/TS (C) catalyst. In order to investigate the reasons for the different STYMA on these three catalysts, the variation trend of STYMA with the amount of Cu+ and the specific surface area of Cu+ (SCu(I)) are illustrated, respectively (see Fig. S7 and Fig.11 (a)). The results show that the STYMA is directly related to the amount and specific surface area of the Cu+ species, which indicate that the Cu+ species are the dominated factor for the carbonylation of methanol to MA. Combined with the results of CO-FTIR, we can infer that more surface Cu+ species and larger SCu(I) on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst result in larger adsorption capacity of CO, promoting the insertion of CO to generate more MA. Whereas the other two catalysts obtain less Cu+ species and smaller SCu(I), resulting in the lower STY of MA. Furthermore, it is found that the STYMA per Cu+ site shows an opposite trend with the SCu(I) (see Fig.S8),which gets the maximum value of 11.413 h−1 over the 10Cu/TS (C) catalyst. It is reasonable to infer that the STYMA per Cu+ site may have an obvious correlation with the Cu particle size. As illustrated in Fig.11 (b), the STYMA per Cu+ site linearly declines with the increasing Cu particle size over these catalysts, proving that methanol carbonylation to MA is a structure-sensitive reaction on the Cu/TS catalyst [65]. In addition, the STYMF gets the maximum of 1.022 mol/h.kgcat on the 10Cu/TS (C) catalyst. As reported in the literature, MF can be produced by dehydrogenation or carbonylation of methanol [66–68]. So it is necessary to clarify whether the formation of MF requires the participation of CO. Therefore, N2 is used instead of CO in the methanol conversion experiments under the same conditions, and the results are shown in Table S1. It is found that MF is still formed with high yield, accompanied by the formation of DME. This fully demonstrates that CO does not participate in the formation of MF. Therfore, MF is formed on these catalysts by the dehydrogenation of methanol. Furthermore, the Cu+ species are mainly responsible for activating the CO molecule, which is absent in N2 atmosphere. That is to say, the synthesis of MF has nothing to do with the Cu+ species. Moreover, the selectivity of MF on these three catalysts is similar. This may be because they have similar content of Cu° species on the surface, which is consistent with the previous conclusion. And the specific reaction mechanism will be studied in the future. In the carbonylation progress, the STYDME reaches the maximum of 3.313 mol/h.kgcat over the TS support. And it is known from the results of NH3-TPD that the support only has weak acid sites. This fully indicates that the dehydration of methanol to DME can easily occur, even in the weak acid sites. After loading copper, the STYDME decreases drastically while the amount of acid sites does not decrease on the 10Cu/TS (N) and 10Cu/TS (C) catalysts. There are two possible reasons for this phenomenon: (1) The synthesis of MA and DME may be parallel competing reactions, both of which require the participation of acidic sites. The existence of the surface Cu+ species on the Cu/TS catalyst can promote the formation of MA, thus inhibiting the formation of DME. (2) MA may be formed by the carbonylation of DME on the Cu/TS catalysts, which results in the decline of STYDME [24,69,70]. In order to explore which reason exactly leads to the decrease of STYDME, DME is used as raw material instead of methanol (molar ratio: DME/CO = 0.5 methanol/CO) for the carbonylation experiments over these three Cu/TS catalysts under the same reaction conditions. It is found that DME does not react directly with CO to form MA. This is probably because the activation of DME requires strong acid sites [25], which are absent on the Cu/TS catalyst. This result shows that the decrease of the STYDME on the Cu/TS catalysts is caused by the first reason rather than the second reason. In order to further explore the effect of surface acidity of the catalysts on the STYDME, it is necessary to exclude the effect of the Cu+ species. Therefore, the conversion of methanol under the N2 atmosphere is carried out. It is found that the STYDME is closely related to the surface acidity of the catalysts under these circumstances (see in Fig.10 (b)). And the maximum of STYDME (3.823 mol/h.kgcat) is obtained on the 10Cu/TS (C) catalysts, which has the most acid sites. 4 Conclusions In the vaper phase carbonylation of methanol to MA, the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst obtained a better catalytic activity than the 10Cu/TS (N) and 10Cu/TS (C) catalysts. The structure, surface copper valence distribution as well as surface acidity of the Cu/TS catalysts were analyzed to clarify the reason. It was found that the copper chloride precursor was mainly connected to the Ti-O-Si bond, resulting in more isolated Cu2+ species. While the other two copper precursors were mainly connected to the Si-O-Si bond to yield more oligomeric (or bulk) CuO species. The isolated Cu2+ species not only promoted the dispersion of copper on the support, but also had a stronger interaction with the support. As a result, the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst obtained the most surface Cu+ species after the same reduction process, which were favorable for the activation of CO. So the highest STYMA was obtained on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst, with the value of 1.619 mol/h.kgcat. Furthermore, the STYMA for per Cu+ site got a maximum value of 11.413 h−1 over the 10Cu/TS (C) catalyst, which was inversely proportional to the copper particle size. This phenomenon proved that the carbonylation of methanol to MA was a structure-sensitive reaction on the Cu/TS catalyst. In addition, the experimental results under the N2 atmosphere showed that MF was produced by the dehydrogenation of methanol, which was related to the Cu° species. And the formation of DME was related to the surface acidity of the catalyst, which competed with the synthesis of MA. Combined with the above results, the conversion of methanol was found proportional to the amount of all acid sites on the catalyst surface, achieving the maximum on the 10Cu/TS (C) catalyst. coredata.dc:description: In the present study, three kinds of copper/titania-silica mixed oxides (Cu/TS) catalysts were prepared using copper chloride, copper nitrate, and copper acetate as copper precursors by the sol-gel method. The catalytic performance was tested in the vapor phase carbonylation of methanol free of halide. The characterization results showed that the interaction between copper and support was the strongest on the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst, leading to the highest copper dispersion and the most surface Cu+ species. As a result, the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst obtained the largest absorption capacity of CO and the maximum amount of Lewis acid sites. The catalytic performance results showed that the space time yield (STY) of methyl acetate (MA) was positively correlated with the content of surface Cu+ species and the specific surface area of the Cu+ cations (SCu(I)). Therefore, the 10Cu/TS (Cl) catalyst obtained the highest STYMA of 1.619 mol/h.kgcat. Moreover, the STYMA per Cu+ site was inversely proportional to the copper particle size, indicating that the carbonylation of methanol to MA is a structure-sensitive reaction. And the methanol conversion was positively correlated with the amount of surface acid sites. Furthermore, the active sites for the synthesis of methyl formate and dimethyl ether were also studied.
coredata.dc:title: Carbonylation of methanol to methyl acetate over Cu/TiO2-SiO2 catalysts: Influence of copper precursors
